title: PayPal's crypto strategy with SVP Jose Fernandez da Ponte

rawLines.text: Hello and welcome to the Cryptobe. My
name is Tim Copeland and I'm the
editor-inchief of the blog. Joining me
today we have Jose Fernandez Deonte,
senior vice president of blockchain,
crypto and digital currencies. Welcome
to the show. How are you doing? Doing
fine, Tim.
Awesome. Before we get started, just
quick note. If you're hiring in crypto,
make sure to check out Campus. Uh, it's
the block's newest hiring tool that of
all your candidates will help you pick
out the real crypto natives. Enter the
block.co/campus to get a threemonth free
trial. Now, today's episode is around
PayPal's foray into crypto. But first, I
wanted to ask you, Jose, what drew you
personally to crypto? Uh, wow. That's
that's a a walk down memory lane. Uh,
I've been involved in crypto for it's
going to be 10 years now. uh so around
2015 and the reason I got involved in
crypto was for payments. I've been a
payments person for the last 20 odd
years and I was tinkering with some of
the protocols that were available around
2015 uh when I was working in banking
and I start to look at ways to move
value between bank accounts in in that
case it was Europe to Latin America and
we started to do that on Ripple actually
and way way back then and that's when we
I squinted hard at that say actually
this thing might might be worthy for
payments and that took me down the
rabbit hole and I never look back. So,
I've been doing that since 10 years ago.
I'm full-time for the last six years.
Interesting. And is there any element of
crypto that like fascinates you the
most?
Uh, for me, it's totally around the
ability to move money instantly. As as I
said, I've been working in payments for
more than 20 years now. And when you
look at the payment side and you look at
the fintech side of it, there is a ton
of innovation that has happened in
fintech. and PayPal has been a part of
that. But most of the innovation is
either on the front end or on fraud. So
you look at most of the fintech
companies that have appeared in the last
20 years. What we do is either we
provide a more convenient way to do
something that you were able to do
already or we address how to prevent
fraud in in places where people are
interacting online and cards are are are
not present. When I started to get
involved in this in 2015, but then more
even more strongly in 2019 as the new
protocols were coming up, we're saying
look this is the first time that I've
seen a technology that has the ability
to fundamentally change how we move
value. If you look at there there's a
reason why wire transfers are called
wire transfers. It is because they were
designed to run on telegram wires. So we
we're using technology that was that
started 100 years ago. Um and when you
look at critical rails and uh AC
transfers, you're talking about
technology that is by now 50 years old.
Uh when we have it's not very often that
you come up with an opportunity of doing
something that really really really re
really builds the thing again from from
the ground up and that's what has been
the most exciting aspect for me. And
PayPal first entered the crypto space in
2020. Looking back, how do you think it
progress has been? Uh yeah, we're
talking at the beginning you open with
the PayPal's fora into crypto. It's a
it's a five year fora and I think that
we are on year five of a 10-y year
journey. Uh it has worked really well
when when you look back to the history
of what we did. We did launch our first
consumerf facing crypto product in in
2020 was the ability to buy Bitcoin and
ETH and a couple of other tokens on the
PayPal wallet and we have been making a
steady progress basically on on three
buckets. The first part of the story was
distribution of crypto to mainstream
consumers. There was a moment in
which way back then in 2020 and
2021 there were a lot of people who were
interested in in starting to get
exposure to digital currencies and
people were saying hey I want to buy
$100 of Bitcoin because I want to to
start to tinker with it but I don't know
what elliptic cryptography is and I
don't know what a non-custodial wallet
is and I don't want to do past phrases
and I don't know the company I I don't
know the brands of the companies who are
on the on the crypto exchanges but I
know PayPal and and so we made it very
EC. We were kind of a gateway product
into crypto for many people and there
was a moment in in 2020 and 21 where the
vast for the vast majority of our crypto
users we were their first crypto
experience and then many of them stayed
with us uh along the journey. Some of
them graduated to to go do DeFi and
other explorations that we did not
support in the platform yet. So in that
first bucket of let's make it very easy
for a mainstream user to get into crypto
that took the first the probably the
first couple of years then we had a
really really big milestone around I
think it was 2022 when we enable onchain
transfers because that really changed
the profile of our business. We still
have those folks who are kind of
cryptocurious who want to explore and
trust the brand. But we are also now
serving a smaller number of much more
active users who are people who are
saying, "Hey, I'm a more sophisticated
crypto user, but I really want a very
easy, very convenient on ramp and off."
So we have a ton of people now who do
more volume but they they find us
because they say hey I really want to
buy ETH quickly with my fiat instrument
and then send it on chain and go do
something on on defy or or in some other
part of the ecosystem. And those folks
are the majority of the business that
that we do today. And then the third
part of it was obviously the launch of
our stable coin of PayUSD in
2023 which again was another inflection
point in in the business and and we are
very heavily working now on both
increasing the distribution of PIUSD in
the ecosystem is supported on more than
25 exchanges and and wallets but also
making sure that we embed it in payment
experiences that we support because the
stable coin the way we look at it is
tokenized balance. It's not technically
tokenized balance but is if you people
have been used to their PayPal balance
and their memo balance for many years
and we wanted to provide an instrument
that
is equal to that but has the added
benefit that you can use it outside of
the PayPal ecosystem. So those have been
distribution, access to digital
currencies, establishment of pure USD in
the ecosystem in as a permissionless
token and and the uniqueness of our
stable coin is the access to the
merchant and consumer base on the on the
PayPal and Bemo side. So continue to
build payment use cases on uh on it are
the three areas where we continue to
build. And amongst sort of those areas,
where are you seeing the highest demand
um from consumers?
Consumers reach out to us when they tell
us we we we periodically ask them what
they would like to see in the
platform. And on the consumer side very
consistently they are saying that they
would like us to support more tokens and
they would like to have an opportunity
to generate some type of reward on the
on the holdings that they have. Those
are the two preeminent and and then a
longer tale of of other features. So we
are looking into into that. There is we
will never probably be the place where
you go to find 250 tokens. Uh it is our
experience is a custodial experience
that is embedded on the PayPal and
wallets. So it's a it's an app that does
other things in addition to crypto and
we want to to keep it relatively
constrained in the number of tokens that
we will support. But we will continue to
add tokens that we think are high
quality and they have a utility and a
developer ecosystem behind them. As an
example of that, we very recently added
support to Solana and and link on on the
platform and has been very well received
by by the community. So the buy
wholesale part of it continues to be
relevant. The other aspect that we see
on on the merchant side
is people want the ability to move
stable coins around for crypto capital
markets use cases but also for other use
cases. So we are seeing adoption
especially on B2B cases. Part of what we
have been doing
is on Zoom which is the PayPal's
remittance product. We have introduced a
stable coin actually at two different
levels on the stack. On the one side we
added it on the consumerf facing aspect.
Let's say that I grew up in Spain. I'm
sending money to my family in Spain. I
can fund my remittance in a stable coin
in the US and then it's basically a
transaction fee. We don't charge any
fees for that and my family would still
receive that as euros in their bank
account in Spain. That's the consumerf
facing piece. Even probably more
importantly, we have added in some
corridors the ability to do a B2B
transfer. Meaning that my experience
would still be the same. I would be
let's use Philippines, which is one of
the corridors where we do this. I want
to send money to my family in the
Philippines. I send dollars here from my
bank account. My family receives
Filipino pesos in their bank account,
but the transaction ledger has moved to
a stable coin. So th those type of
experiences that are kind of fiat on the
front, but a stable coin in the back. I
think that's one of the places where you
will see the as gateway experiences for
mainstream adoption of stables. And you
mentioned like yield as as something
that the consumers are are looking for.
I mean this is obviously quite common in
crypto like in Coinbase you can get like
4% on USDC for instance. Um are you
considering like different ways that you
could introduce yield products? We we're
looking at it. There are a number of
regulatory components on on that on on
how you can go about it. there is but
definitely we see that there is a lot of
consumer interest so we will we will
explore it uh as you were saying it's
relatively common in the in the crypto
sector so it's it's a good avenue to
think about but for the moment we have
focused much more on on adding to the
list of tokens that that we could
support and then you said you're going
to adopt a fairly sort of conservative
strategy uh on the stable coins you
mentioned sort of the three things
you're most looking for how many sort of
assets do do you anticipate PayPal
adding sort of over the next few years?
Uh I don't have a number if in mind. A
lot of that is going to be defined by
the quality of the assets and also by
how much we can support on on the
platform purely from a user experience.
Again, if you go into a
mainstream we don't want to be the most
comprehensive crypto wallet for traders.
That wouldn't make sense for us. We want
we don't want to be better at being an
exchange than than than the exchanges
are. But we definitely want to be the
best mainstream wallet for crypto users.
We want to make sure that we can provide
enough that people when they're
accessing their ecosystems, they can go
and and find the tokens that they they
want with us. I don't believe that we'll
probably get into the space of mecoins.
We are we are interested in tokens that
can
provide
utility with a high level even with a
high level of abstraction for a payment
use case that we were interested in link
uh because oracles are going to be
important if you really want to drive
commercial activity. Solana obviously we
deployed the our stable coin on Solana
last year. So it's obviously a a
protocol that is very amenable to
payment use cases when we find more
tokens where we are saying a high
quality strong developer activity
utility and and adjacent at least to
payment use cases. Those are probably
those that are going to be higher
priority for us. And you mentioned
regulation. How difficult is it to be a
sort of very established payments
company while also being trying to sort
of adopt and experiment with sort of a
new technology that's has a bit more of
an uncertain regulatory environment. I
would say that is it is difficult. It is
also the job. I think that that's for
for all of us who are on on on the
industry. If you look at it I'm talking
now about the financial services
industry more than the crypto native
industry. Uh there are a couple of ways
in which you can go about it. You can
follow what we decided that that was the
right path for us which is we are seeing
a technology that can fundamentally
redefine our domain of business. It
would be responsible from us not to have
a horse in the race. So we need to
explore it. We have been very gradual
and incremental and we have been
building our stack and we have been
extremely rigorous on on the regulatory
and compliance side. So we we got the
first we got our first bit bid license
in 20 well we launched in 2020 we got
with a uh we got our full bid license in
2021 we have establish uh we got a trust
license in in New York as well we have
built a lot of things that ride on top
of the existing risk frameworks of
PayPal. So we have been very deliberate
on building it with a very very high
regulatory standard. We're talking about
legislation and and the framework. One
of the reasons why we wanted to issue
the stable coin out of New York and we
came to Paxos uh for the issuance of our
stable coin is because New York has a
very clear regulatory structure for
stable coins and we thought this is the
highest regulatory bar in the land and
we want to be in the places that that
where we can stand by the the strongest
and the more strict supervision. Is it
difficult? Yes, it is difficult but it's
also what provides a head start. If you
look at there is now because the other
avenue is is let's sit on the sidelines
of this thing. Let's wait for the
regulator environment to get everything
be very very crystal clear. let's not
take any any any risk and then we'll
move in when things are clear and if you
look at that and that's a very
respectful strategy that you can follow
as well and that's what a ton of the
financial institutions are these days
especially in the US we're saying hey
there seems to be a stable coin bill
that is going to pass it's going to get
more clear and everybody's now looking
at the space and saying how do we get
into it we believe that the work that we
have done over the last six years gives
us a head start and hopefully we're
going to be able to move faster than
than competition now faster than
competition in fintex and financial
institutions
and with Trump coming into power and
sort of a new crypto friendly SEC
chairman does this change PayPal
strategy at all now the sort of
environment seem to be a bit more
positive or or does it does the strategy
stay the same it it doesn't change the
the strategy as as we said at the
beginning we are on year five of a
10-year journey so the the the main
principles and the primitives of what we
are trying to build are the
Obviously with when when the environment
in the US gets more clear, it will allow
us probably to move faster and it will
allow us to expand the the portfolio of
features that we can offer to clients
faster. There is not a change in
direction because the direction was very
very well established. Probably the
speed at which we can execute gets gets
faster and it's not only about the US.
And that is important the developments
that have happened in Europe with Mika
being implemented now what is going on
in in Singapore in other jurisdictions
like in in the Middle East
Japan the UK we tend to focus a ton on
what's going on in the US because
obviously that's where a lot of the
industry is is based but in general I
think that you can see a secular trend
about the regulation getting more clear
globally and um what has been the
adoption rate among PayPal users for
crypto as a payment method.
Uh so let me maybe break that down in in
two parts. Adoption in in of digital
currencies in general on our platform,
PayPal obviously has a very broad
customer
base and in the places where our crypto
product is live which now is in the US
and and also in the UK and and in
Luxembourg is our European market. Now,
especially in the US, I would say that
our population reflects the population
as as a whole. So, you're seeing similar
rates of adoption that you would see in
the the overall population. And we run a
longitudinal study of consumers that
we've been running by year for years now
where we constantly ask
people, do you hold or have you held in
the past digital currencies? And I think
that cons consistently we are seeing in
the US adoption rates that
are slightly past the moment of just
hardcore early adopters. I think that we
are getting I wouldn't claim that crypto
is mainstream by any means but awareness
is very high and if you ask people
how how many of them have experiences
with crypto and stable coins and NFTs I
think that you we're starting to be
beyond that initial that arbitrary 10%
rate of early adopters. So I think that
we are getting to the moment in which
you start to see the acceleration of
that curve and our
adoption I think is a reflection of that
population as as a whole. We have
millions of folks who have been on
boarded on our on our crypto product and
and we hope that that's going to
continue to to evolve over time. The
second part of your question there was
about
payments adoption for payments is still
small. I think that we see that across
uh across the sector and part of that is
something that we need to solve as an
industry which is what we call the call
star pro uh program. Right? It is very
clear if you're a merchant now the
advantages of adopting stable coins are
quite clear. So you're going to get
probably
lower payment costs. You're going to
have instant settlement. You can receive
funds 247. You can settle funds over
weekends. You can send money worldwide.
You don't you're not dependent on wire
transfers. So you're a when I'm having a
conversation with a treasurer or CFO and
I'm pitching payments in stable coins on
the business both the enterprise and the
SMB side, the value proposition for a
merchant to say yes is quite clear.
If you're a consumer in the US or in
Europe or in places that have a very
high credit card penetration and people
are used to the rewards and their cash
back and all of that and there is not
really a pain point about obtaining a
credit card, I don't think that we have
solved yet the value proposition for the
consumer. That's different in in
emerging markets. So you go to places
like Africa or Southeast Asia or Latin
America or places where it's more
difficult to have a credit
card that value prop is very clear. Hey,
this will allow you to do payments that
are cheaper or or even do them at all if
you don't have a a credit card. That's
why I believe that that's where you have
seen adoption for payments so far is
both on the merchants and on on on
regions that are outside the US and and
Europe.
Part of what the the job ahead for us
and for others who want to be in that in
this space is let's provide compelling
value propositions for consumers so that
they are willing and and able to have
crypto wallets that carry stable coins
and they want to pay with them because I
think that's the moment where you start
to kick in those network effects is
going to happen but it's going to happen
over a period of time. That's why I we
are very focused now on enabling those
payment use cases but also focusing a
ton on B2B and crossber payments because
I believe that's where the the adoption
is going to happen first. Yesterday
Circle announced uh a crossber payments
network uh that's focusing on stable
coins. I was curious what did you what
did you make of this announcement? Uh I
I saw some coverage in the media. I
didn't really see the announcement. I
I'm looking forward to seeing the the
announcement
because welcome to the game. I think
that circle has been obviously very very
successful at building the market cap of
of USDC. Building a payments business is
obviously you need to have a base of
consumers and a base of of merchants. I
think it's a good thing to have more
actors in the system who are devoted to
getting the the the public into stable
coin payments. But I but I don't think
I've seen the the announcement from them
yet. So I I cannot bind because I
haven't seen the details.
Yep. And um you've mentioned obviously
the PayPal stable coin quite a bit. Um
it's definitely something we've noticed
a lot recently that stable coins appear
to be one of the sort of biggest things
in crypto with uh real product market
fit and that are also very lucrative uh
for the issuer in many cases. How much
opportunity do you see in the growth of
uh PI USD? We see fantastic opportunity.
So if you look at uh metrics for the
stable coin, we've been in the market
for a little bit more than a year and a
half now. If you look at metrics, the
industry is very fixated in general when
they look at the stable coins with
market cap, which is an interesting one.
We are less fixated with with that. We
look at four things when we look at
adoption of our stable coin as as
measure of success. We look
at number of monthly transactions,
number of active wallets every month,
onchain transfer volume and then and and
we do look at market cap but the re but
as a fourth metric and the reason we do
that is we are building our stable coins
for payments and there are a number of
ways in which we can monetize payment
transactions. The industry looks a lot
at market cap because issuers today
mostly monetize their stable coin on the
yield on the reserve and therefore
obviously if you're making yield on on
the reserve assets the larger the amount
of assets the larger the monetization
and and and the revenue side. If you are
on the payment side there are a number
of ways in which we can monetize that
that are driven much more by velocity
and transactions and and the stable coin
moving around than they are on on the
market cap. We do look at the market cap
but in our minds the market cap is
relevant mostly because it's a proxy for
liquidity. So you want to have enough of
a market cap. I think that we are now we
are our universe is fiatback stable
coins that are non-native geing issued
in the US. If you look at that
environment we are probably the second
largest stable coin in the US. Now if
you look globally and you include
cryptocolateralize and native jbearing
and all that we're probably the eighth
but most of those are not used for for
commerce and payments. So we want to
make sure that when a remittance player
or when a company that is providing B2B
payments wants to enable a corridor that
there is enough liquidity in the market
that an enterprise will be wouldn't say
yeah I'm going to move my money in
stable in in PI USD because when PUD
gets to let's say Australia there is
enough liquidity in Australia to move
quickly from PUD to Australian dollar
that that's a utility of market cap for
us the Gund reserve we don't care a lot
about it for a number of reasons first
of all we have other ways of monitoring
izing that and I guess that probably
that's one of reasons why other players
you were talking about circle comments
of getting into payments maybe that's
one of the reasons that they're
interested in finding alternative ways
to to monetize but I'm great in there is
so you have we have other ways of uh
monetizing
second yield on the reserve is obviously
a function of interest rates and
eventually you believe that interest
rates will be compressed then those
revenues are going to be under more
pressure than they are today and Third,
I do believe that with clarity on
legislation with Mika being implemented
in the US that we will see an emergence
of new users and new issuers and people
who will be sending issuing new stable
coins. So I believe that part of that
revenue is going to get competed away.
So is going to be deployed and uh for
for the benefit of users if you look at
those three things that's why yes market
cap is a factor in our equation. If I
had to pick one, I care much more about
onchain transfer volume than I care
about market cap. Do you think PayPal
would ever add other stable coins to its
platform? Never say never. I think that
in when a big principle for us is
consumer choice and and that's something
that goes beyond crypto. It's part of
the DNA of of the company. We we love it
when people pay with the PayPal balance
at a transaction. But we will respect
how people want to pay. They want to use
their credit card or the debit card or
bank account or or something else. We
will respect that. So far we have not
seen a ton of interest or or demand and
people saying as hey you should enable
stable coin X or stable coin Y. People
want one stable coin and I think that at
some point in time you're going to see
that people will think of stable coins
as digital dollars and the specific
brands might be relevant or or not but
we have not seen a ton of demand for
people to say hey we really really
really would want you to support this
other stable coin. If that happens, we
will consider it because again, consumer
choice is is an important parameter for
us. And PayPal stable coin is currently
the eighth uh biggest stable coin with a
supply of around 800 million. Yep. Do
you think it has a shot at rivaling
Tether for the number one spot?
Uh Tether is what 160 billion. We are we
are a long ways from that now. And uh I
look I'll give you a little bit of my
worldview of what what I think this is
all going to evolve. I think that PD is
going to is going to become larger than
than it is. I think that we will see
that again if you look at our history
for the past five years it has very
deliberative very deliberate reasonably
conservative and upward trend and I
expect that that's what you're going to
see with with our stable coin as well.
So it's going to be bigger than than
than it is now. My second point going
back to what I just said about market
cap. We're not chasing market cap as a
metric. I think that is important for
issuers who monetize those deals on the
reserve aggressively. It's less
important for us. So I I'm definitely I
would love to be as big as tether in
terms of payment volume and and and
global adoption. And definitely that's
something where we have an ambition to
be the preeminent stable coin for
payments. market cap chasing them or
circle or any anyone else on market cap
is not a priority that we are that we
are very focused on and then I think
that the market structure for the stable
coins will will change if you look at
the market structure
today what is the market share of the
top two stable coins is what is 80% of
the total market cap or or more I think
that probably what you will see
is again and partially driven by
legislation in the US. I think that what
you're going to see is a bunch of new
stable coins center in the market from a
different number of issuers. There are
probably going to be smaller in volume
than that top
two, but probably what you're going to
have is a bunch of the stable coins. I
don't know what it is. I know it's not
3,000, but it's definitely more than
two. So you're going to see a bunch of
stable coins that have market caps in
the billions but maybe not in the tens
of billions and that they are very
interoperable because they're issued on
the same on the same protocols. And I
think that's a more sustainable model
for for the industry. So yeah, we're
going to get bigger. You'll see others
launching probably that are going to be
in in that same ballpark. And I don't
know what's that's going to do uh it's
anyone's guess what that do does to the
to the situation of others because
hopefully the pie is going to get larger
as as well. But going back to your
question, I'm not obsessed about chasing
anyone on market cap. I I want to see a
multiplicity of a stable coins in the
market. I think this is a that's going
to be a healthy market structure. There
was um one kind of data point I was
curious about like we saw the supply on
Salana drop from a peak of around 660
million to around 130 million. Do you
know why there was such sort of a large
decrease there? Uh yeah I think that it
went that that happened a couple of
years ago. Yeah. The Solan ecosystem is
very driven, at least part of that is
very driven by by DeFi pools and and I
think that they reacted really well
to our launch in the market and and to
the very good work the Solar Foundation
and others have done to foster adoption
in in the ecosystem and then it it did
correct but it established at a level
that was definitely higher than than at
at launch. So you it was sometimes you
you see that you see very very steep
adoption early and then it it goes back
to a more
sustainable level which is fine. And
what do you make of Black Rockck making
sort of big moves into crypto with you
know the Bidd uh token? Do do you think
it's interesting to see such a large
sort of financial company also getting
involved in sort of a similar approach?
I think it's fantastic news. I think
that Black Rockck has been a
Not not only with Bidd, they have also
been more active in terms of managing
assets and driving the Bitcoin ETFs. I
think that having large financial
players that see the value of this
technology and and getting in that
space is fundamentally important because
a lot
of part of the promise of of blockchains
is based on technology, but a lot of
that is going to be driven by
distribution. So having platforms like
Blro or like PayPal or others who have
large distribution networks and can make
this available quickly for the people
who don't want to be running around with
non-custodial wallets and and getting
into the the complexity and the very
very advanced users is super important.
So I think that if you look at the last
five years or so, I like to think that
we were part of the early wave of
adoption of financial institutions
getting into crypto. The asset managers
in the US have definitely been very
active over the last two or three years.
It's not only Black Rockck is you see
Black Rockck, you see Fidelity, you see
Franken Templeton, you see Wisdom Tree,
you see a number of the asset managers
who have been getting into into the
space and I hope that between this year
